case_name: M/s K.S. Rashid & Son v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 37-40 of 1963 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 37-40 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals Nos. 37-40 of 1963 arise from Allahabad High Court judgment dated August 13, 1959 in Writ Petitions Nos. 870 to 873 and 349 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated August 13, 11, 1959 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Petitions Nos. 870 to 873 and 349 of 1956 respectively.

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 335 to 345 of 1960 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: WITH Petitions Nos. 335 to 345 of 1960. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: M/s K. S. Rashid & Son and partner Rashid Ahmad are appellants in Civil Appeals Nos. 37-40 of 1963 and petitioners in W.Ps. Nos. 335-345/1960.

anchor.surface_text: M s. K. S. Rashid Son, and its partner, Rashid Ahmad, are the appellants in Civil Appeals Nos. 37 to 40/1963, and petitioners in W.Ps. Nos. 335-345/1960.

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 870-873 of 1956 filed by the firm and partner in Allahabad High Court challenging notices under s.34(1A) for assessment years 1941-42 to 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals arise out of the four writ petitions  Nos. 870-873 of 1956  filed by the firm and its partner in the High Court of Allahabad challenging the validity of the numberices served upon them under s. 34 1A  of the Act in respect of their income for the years 1941-42 to 1946-47.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed writ petitions 870-873 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: These writ petitions have been dismissed by the said High Court and it is with the certificate issued by it that the firm and its partner have companye to this Court in appeal.

facts.text: Notices served on M/s K.S. Rashid & Son on 19th March 1956 under s.34(1A) and excess profit tax levied.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions Nos. 335-345/1960 have been filed by the same parties in this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution in respect of the numberices served on them on the 19th March. 1956 and the order of excess profit tax levied on them.

facts.text: Respondents in appeals include Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., Lucknow and Income-tax Officer, Central Circle IV, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents to the appeals are the Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., Lucknow, and the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle IV, Delhi.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 589 of 1963 filed by M/s Bhawani Prasad Girdharlal challenging notice issued on 16th August 1955 under s.34(1A).

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 589 of 1963 has been brought to this Court in similar circumstances by the appellant, M s. Bhawani Prasad Girdharlal. The appellant had challenged the validity of the numberices issued to it on the 16th August, 1955 under s. 3 4  1A  of the Act.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed writ petition of M/s Bhawani Prasad Girdharlal.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition filed by the appellant has been dismissed by the Allahabad High Court and it is with the certificate issued by the said High Court that the present appeal has been brought to this Court.

facts.text: Case heard on February 19, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Attorney-General, K. N. Rajagopal Sastri and R. N. Sachthey, for the respondents  in all the appeals and petitions . February 19, 1964.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment-of the Court was, delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, C.J.-These civil appeals and writ petitions have been placed before us for hearing in a group,

facts.text: Section 34(1A) of Income-tax Act, 1922 introduced by amendment on 17th July, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the companystruction of s. 34 1A , it would be necessary to refer very briefly to the background of the enactment of the said section. This section was introduced by an amendment in the Act on the 17th July, 1954,

facts.text: Section 54 of Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947 struck down as unconstitutional on May 28, 1954 in Suraj Mall Mohta v. A.V. Viswanatha Sastri.

anchor.surface_text: and that was because s. 5  4  of the Taxation on Income  Investigation Commission  Act  No. 30 of 1947  was struck down by this Court as unconstitutional on May 28, 1954, in Suraj Mall Mohta and Another v. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri and Another 1 .

facts.text: Section 51 of Investigation Commission Act struck down in Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Sri A.V. Viswanatha Sastri.

anchor.surface_text: In Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai v. Sri A. V. Viswanatha Sastri and Another 1 , a point was raised before this Court as to whether it was open to the Income-tax Department to invoke s. 5 1  of the Investigation Commission Act after s. 34 1A  of the Act was enacted,

facts.text: s.34(1A) applies to income escaping assessment for previous years falling within 1st September 1939 to 31st March 1946 where escaped income >= Rs.1 lakh.

anchor.surface_text: This provision lays down, inter alia, that if, in any case of an assessee. the Income-tax Officer has reason to-believe that income has escaped assessment for any year in respect of which the relevant previous year falls wholly or partly within the period beginning on the 1st day of September, 1939, and ending on the 31st day of March, 1946 and that the said income amounts, or is likely to amount, to Rs. 1 lakh or more,

facts.text: No notice under s.34(1A) after 31st March 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that numbersuch numberice shall be issued after the 31st day of March, 1956.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court in Jai Kishan Srivastava v. ITO held s.34(1A) valid (majority view).

anchor.surface_text: That is the effect of the majority view taken by the Allahabad High Court in Jai Kishan Srivastava v. Income-tax Officer, Kanpur and Another 1 .

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.34(1A) valid and does not contravene Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we must hold that s. 34 1A  is valid and has number companytravened Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: All Civil Appeals and Writ Petitions dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, all the Civil Appeals and Writ Petitions in this group fail and are dismissed.

facts.text: In CA 589/1963, appellant argued no reasons recorded by ITO as per proviso to s.34(1A), but court notes it was assumed reasons were recorded.

anchor.surface_text: There is one minor additional point which has been argued before us by Mr. Setalvad in Civil Appeal No. 589 of 1963, ... Now, when we look at the pleadings of the parties, it is clear that it was assumed by the appellant that reasons had been recorded and in fact, it was positively affirmed by the respondent that they had been so recorded

facts.text: War period from 1st September 1939 to 31st March 1946 saw huge profits in business and industry.

anchor.surface_text: It is well--known that that is the period in which as a result of the War, huge profits were made in business and industry.

facts.text: s.34(1) provides 8 years limitation for cl.(a) cases, 4 years for cl.(b).

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the first category of cases, s. 34 1  had provided at the relevant time that the Income- tax Officer may, in cases falling under cl.  a  at any time within eight years, and in cases falling under clause  b  at any time within four years of the end of that year,

facts.text: Investigation Commission ceased to function after s.51 struck down.

anchor.surface_text: That is how, s. 5 1  became a dead letter and the Investigation Commission, in companysequence, ceased to function.

facts.text: Cases referred to Investigation Commission but not completed taken up under s.34(1A).

anchor.surface_text: The cases which had been referred to that Commission and which had number been companypleted had, therefore, to be taken up under s. 34 1A  of the Act.

issues.text: the validity of s. 34 1A of the Act

anchor.surface_text: That is how the only question which arises for our decision in this group of matters relates to the validity of s. 34 1A  of the Act.

issues.text: whether the omission in s. 34 1A of the words 'as if the notice were a notice issued under that sub-section' deprives assessees of remedies by way of appeals and revisions, contravening Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: contravened Art. 14 of the Constitution. It is urged that whereas under s. 34 1 which deals with similar cases of assessees, the remedy by way of appeals and revisions under the relevant provisions of the Act is available to the assessees, that remedy is denied to the assessees against whom proceedings are taken under the impugned section.

issues.text: what is the effect of the omission to include in s. 34 1A the clause as if the notice were a notice issued under that sub-section which is to be found in s. 34 1

anchor.surface_text: Reverting then to the question of construction, the narrow point which needs to be examined is, what is the effect of the omission to include in s. 34 1A  the clause as if the notice were a notice issued under that sub-section which is to be found in s. 34 1 ?

issues.text: whether absence of limitation period in s. 34 1A unlike s. 34 1 contravenes Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: The other contention raised against the validity of s.34 1A  is based on the fact that at the relevant time, s. 34 1  a  dealt with cases similar to those falling under s.34 1A , and yet, whereas in the former category of cases a period of limitation was prescribed as eight years there is no such limitation in regard to the latter, and that, it is urged, means unconstitutional discrimination.

issues.text: whether the requirement prescribed by the proviso to s. 34 1A that the Income-tax Officer shall not issue a notice unless he has recorded his reasons and CBR is satisfied was complied with

anchor.surface_text: proviso to s. 34 1A  that the Income-tax Officer shall not issue a notice unless he has recorded his reasons for doing so, and the Central Board of Revenue is satisfied on such reasons recorded that it is a fit case for the issue of such notice

arguments.claim: Section 34(1A) contravenes Article 14 because it denies remedies by way of appeals and revisions available under Section 34(1) to similarly placed assessees

anchor.surface_text: The argument urged in support of the challenge to the validity of the impugned section is that it suffers from the vice of contravening Art. 14 of the Constitution. It is urged that whereas under s. 34 1 which deals with similar cases of assessees, the remedy by way of appeals and revisions under the relevant provisions of the Act is available to the assessees, that remedy is denied to the assessees against whom proceedings are taken under the impugned section.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: suffer from the infirmity that it companytravenes Art. 14. Though, as we will later point out, there is a rational classification between the assessee

arguments.court_reasoning: Omission of specific phrase does not deprive remedies; harmonious construction, purposive intent from background, notice referable to s.22(2), provisions apply 'thereupon'; absurd otherwise (no s.23 powers)

arguments.claim: Section 34(1A) contravenes Article 14 because it provides no period of limitation unlike 8 years under Section 34(1)(a) for similar cases

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 1 thus gives a preferential treatment to the assessees who are similarly placed with the assessees dealt with under s. 34 1A and that amounts to unconstitutional discrimination. It is also urged that in regard to cases falling under s. 34 1 a as it stood at the relevant time, a period of limitation of 8 years had been prescribed beyond which the assessing authority could not act, and this protection of the prescribed period of limitation is not available to the assessees against whom action is taken under the impugned section.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sessees who are companyered by s. 34 1A , cannot be sustained. The other companytention raised against the validity of s.34 1A  is based on the fact t

arguments.court_reasoning: Rational classification: limited to war period 1939-1946 with escaped income >= Rs.1 lakh (huge war profits); intelligible nexus to recover large escapes; overlap with s.34(1)(a) immaterial as procedure/remedies same

arguments.claim: Proviso to Section 34(1A) condition precedent not satisfied as no reasons recorded by ITO and CBR not satisfied

anchor.surface_text: There is one minor additional point which has been argued before us by Mr. Setalvad in Civil Appeal No. 589 of 1963, and that point is based upon the requirement prescribed by the proviso to s. 34 1A that the Income-tax Officer shall not issue a notice unless he has recorded his reasons for doing so, and the Central Board of Revenue is satisfied on such reasons recorded that it is a fit case for the issue of such notice.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ded that it is a fit case for the issue of such numberice. The argument is that the require- I. L. R. 1959 II All. 451. ment prescribed by the proviso

arguments.court_reasoning: Pleadings assume reasons recorded (appellant assumed, respondent affirmed); controversy was entitlement to copy, not absence; assessee not entitled to copy

arguments.claim: Omission in s.34(1A) of phrase 'as if the notice were a notice issued under that sub-section' deprives assessees of appeals/revisions under ss.30-33B, contravening Art.14

anchor.surface_text: It is not seriously disputed that if the notice issued under s. 34 1A is not deemed to be a notice under s. 22 2, the remedies by way of appeals and revisions which are prescribed by sections 30, 31, 32, 33, 33A and 33B of the Act would not be available to the assessee, and so, the main basis for the attack against the validity of s. 34 1A rests on the hypothesis that the omission of the relevant words in s. 34 1A in substance deprives the assessee of the said remedies prescribed by the relevant provisions of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: adurai v. Sri A. V. Viswanatha Sastri and Another 1 , a point was raised before this Court as to whether it was open to the Income-tax Department to i

arguments.claim: Legislature intended s.34(1A) assessees to have same remedies as under s.34(1) to cure invalidity of s.54 Investigation Act

anchor.surface_text: when the legislature enacted s. 34 1A, it must have desired to remove the infirmities which had rendered s. 54 of the Investigation Commission Act invalid. In other words, the legislature must have presumably wanted to afford to the assessees in respect of whom s. 34 1A was intended to be invoked, the same remedies that were available to the assessee covered by s. 34 1.

arguments.claim: Notice under s.34(1A) containing requirements of s.22(2) notice, followed by assessment where provisions apply 'thereupon' and 'accordingly'

anchor.surface_text: the notice which is required to be issued is, in terms, in a sense referable to s. 22 2, because the legislature has provided that it must contain all or any of the requirements which would be included in such a notice. Then, s. 34 1A provides that after issuing the notice on the assessee in the manner prescribed by it, the Income-tax Officer may proceed to assess or reassess the income... thereupon the provisions of this Act shall, so far as may be, apply accordingly.

arguments.claim: Interpreting s.34(1A) without s.22 applicability leads to absurd consequences: no s.23(2) evidence powers, no appeals ss.30-33B

anchor.surface_text: If s. 22 is held to be inapplicable to proceedings under s. 34 1A, the consequence would be entirely irrational and fantastic. The powers conferred on the Income-tax Officer under s. 23 2 to take evidence would then not be available to him, and, indeed, all the powers prescribed and the procedure laid down by s. 23 would become irrelevant. Likewise, the provisions in regard to appeals and revisions contained in sections 30, 31, 33, 33A and 33B would also be inapplicable.

arguments.claim: s.34(1A) follows precedent: enacted post Suraj Mall striking s.54; s.51 struck in Meenakshi post-enactment

anchor.surface_text: This section was introduced by an amendment in the Act on the 17th July, 1954, and that was because s. 54 of the Taxation on Income Investigation Commission Act No. 30 of 1947 was struck down by this Court as unconstitutional on May 28, 1954, in Suraj Mall Mohta... In Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd... s. 51 of the Investigation Commission Act... contravened Art. 14.

arguments.claim: Assessees under s.34(1A) rationally classified from s.34(1): war period 1939-46 huge profits, escaped income >=1 lakh

anchor.surface_text: s. 34 1A is intended to deal with assessees whose income has escaped assessment during a specified period between 1st of September, 1939 and the 31st of March, 1946. It is well-known that that is the period in which as a result of the War, huge profits were made in business and industry... only where the income which has escaped assessment is likely to amount to Rs. 1 lakh or more.

arguments.claim: Overlap between s.34(1)(a) and s.34(1A) for one year immaterial as procedure and remedies identical post-notice

anchor.surface_text: It was suggested that as a result of the provisions contained in s. 34 1 a and s. 34 1A one year would overlap and that may be true. But the argument of overlapping has no significance because it makes no difference whether action is taken under s. 34 1, or s. 34 1A in respect of that year. Once the notice is served under s. 34 1 or s. 34 1A, the rest of the procedure is just the same and all the remedies available to the assessees are also just the same.

arguments.claim: Allahabad High Court majority in Jai Kishan Srivastava held s.34(1A) valid

anchor.surface_text: That is the effect of the majority view taken by the Allahabad High Court in Jai Kishan Srivastava v. Income-tax Officer, Kanpur and Another.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: urged before the High Court by the appellant was number that numberreasons had been recorded by the Income-tax Officer as required by the proviso the

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agrees s.34(1A) valid, no contravention of Art.14

arguments.claim: s.34(1A) valid, does not contravene Art.14

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we must hold that s. 34 1A is valid and has not contravened Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: the challenge made to the validity of s. 34 1A on the ground that the remedy by way of appeals or revisions which is available to the assessees against whom proceedings are taken under s. 34 1 is not available to the assessees who are covered by s. 34 1A, cannot be sustained

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we have no hesitation in holding that the challenge made to the validity of s. 34 1A on the ground that the remedy by way of appeals or revisions which is available to the assessees against whom proceedings are taken under s. 34 1  is not available to the assessees who are covered by s. 34 1A , cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission of phrase not deliberate; notice referable to s.22(2); provisions apply 'thereupon accordingly'; background intent to provide remedies; absurd consequences otherwise (no s.23 powers, no appeals)

holdings.text: we see no substance in the argument that the absence of the restriction as to period of limitation under s. 34 1A introduces any infirmity in the said provision

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we see no substance in the argument that the absence of the restriction as to period of limitation under s. 34 1A  introduces any infirmity in the said provision. In the result, we must hold that s. 34 1A  is valid and has not contravened Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rational classification: s.34(1A) limited to war period 1939-1946 escapes >= Rs.1 lakh (huge profits); intelligible nexus to recover large hidden income; procedure/remedies same as s.34(1); minor overlap immaterial

holdings.text: s. 34 1A is valid and has not contravened Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we must hold that s. 34 1A  is valid and has not contravened Art. 14 of the Constitution. That is the effect of the majority view taken by the Allahabad High Court in Jai Kishan Srivastava v. Income-tax Officer, Kanpur and Another 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects discrimination claims on remedies availability via construction and rational classification for limitation removal; agrees with Allahabad HC majority

holdings.text: the condition precedent prescribed by the proviso had been complied with

anchor.surface_text: we do not see how Mr. Setalvad can suggest that no reasons had in fact been recorded, and so, the condition precedent prescribed by the proviso had not been complied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pleadings show appellant assumed reasons recorded, respondent affirmed; dispute was on entitlement to copy, not absence; assessee not entitled to copy of reasons
